results.brief_description:

results.title: Volcanoes: exploring the restless earth
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: On-location photography and animated drawings illustrate volcanic phenomena in Hawaii, Mexico, Italy and Iceland. The film distinguishes shield, cinder cone and strato-volcano by showing how each type of volcano is formed and how each erupts. Before and after footage of the 1973 destruction of Helgarfjell on Iceland’s Heimaey Island vividly documents the effect of volcanic eruptions on man and his environment. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Volcanoes, earthquakes, and other earth movements
results.creator_credit: Reinald Werrenrath Jr and Goldberg-Werrenrath Productions
results.brief_description: Indicates that volcanoes and earthquakes are evidence of a natural process called plate tectonics. Shows how to chart part movements of these crustal plates and how to make predictions about their movements. The program also uses excellent location film such as the eruption of the Mt St Helens volcano in Norther America. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Volcanoes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Earth”.
Evidence of high termperature and pressure beneath the earth’s surface is seen in bubbling mud pots, hot spering geysers, lava fountains and thunderous volcanic eruptions. Further effects of volcanic action on the earth’s crust are seen in cinder cones, crater lakes, calderas, shield and strato-volcanoes.

results.title: Volcano
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Television, Gail Willumsen and Teresa Koenig
results.brief_description: A detailed documentary on the force and ferocity behind some of the earth’s 1,500 potentially dangerous volcanoes, and the threat they pose to those who live within their reach. Elaborates on some of the more famous volcanoes and eruptions, including Galeras (Colombia), Kilauea (Hawaii), Sakurajima and Unzen (Japan), and Pinatubo (Philippines), using archival footage to show the raw power behind these incredible acts of creation. The experiences of vulcanologists Stanley Williams and Maurice and Katia Krafft are also explored, as are the after-effects of an eruption, volcanoes in history, and current methods of detection and evacuation.

results.title: Volcano
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Alan Probert
results.brief_description: Describes the growth of the volcano Paricutin, which rose suddenly in central Mexico. Sequences cover the volcano’s first eruption in 1943, and its sturdy growth since that time. Shows water vapor, rocks, molten lava, the throat of the cone, and some of the devastation wrought in nearby areas by the slow crushing advance of the lava flow.

results.title: Volcanism
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Earth revealed”.
Volcanoes are often found where the continental plates converge or diverge, or in designated “hot spots” in the middle of plates such as can be found in the Hawaiian region. A handful of special volcanoes formed along rift zones, can also be found. The study of volcanoes and their activities, casts new light on the internal structure of the earth and their impact on other phenomena such as the weather.
